text: <@U0YNFB22X> if ok with you my suggestion would be to wait for the merge process to complete and then resubmit to the final branch.
basically to avoid more churn /delay in getting to one codebase
Ok agreed, makes sense

<@U0YNFB22X> theres no reason to wait, per se…you could just checkout the 1839 CR and work on top of that
totally up to you
i primarily wanted you to be aware that if you dont take action, some of your work will be rolled back
as long as you are aware of that, ill leave it to you to work out the timing

no, since I was one of the authors so I need other maintainers to approve…I hope ASAP since it grows stale with time
but theres also this matter that the UTs feel extra unreliable since the merge
im hoping to rope <@U0XPR4NP4> in for an assist on resolving that, but I dont yet have a feel for how long it might take to resolve it
I reviewed and +2 last night;  if we can get <@U0ULK2JPP> to +2 then we’re good to go — I think we should try to push it through asap

Got it, let me take a look

text: (if you check out the 1839 tree, 4958506ae53 represents the convergence branch before the merge
also note that the pb.go changes are because we merged an upgrade to protobuf
Ah, that makes sense, was wondering why there were changes in the `pb.go` but not the `.proto`
yeah, went from 3.0.0-beta3 to v3.0.2 IIRC
(soon to be v3.1.0, but that is in another stream
getting hard to keep them all straight, heh
but anyway, we re-ran make protos after the merge to make sure the new convergence .protos were accounted for
or at least, that was the intention

so, IMO, if we can gather >=2+2/V+1 and at least one of the +2s is <@U0KM61BCP>, I think its ready to go in
If the CI failures are so common, I'd be of the opinion to add a t.Skip() and open an issue to fix the test
<@U0XPR4NP4> works for me, though I don’t know if we can classify the frequency quite yet
until today, I had only seen it in 1839, and we saw it fairly frequently there, leading me to believe it was caused by 1839
so far, i’ve only seen one other example of it, but it was independent of 1839 leading me to think that 1839 did not have anything to do with it
i guess what still remains unknown is whether 1839 exacerbates it, however

Right.  Especially since this code path should be going away, I'd be more inclined to skip the test, as CI failures slow everyone down, but I understand even a higher frequency failure could indicate regression which we most certainly do not want
right
i have a feeling that the issue is either latent, or timing sensitive and the timing changed slightly
(as opposed to newly introduced regression)
but that is just gut instinct
Right, that is my assessment as well, will keep trying to track down an actual fix though
ok, cool…well, lets see if we can amass the appropriate approval and go from there
<@U0KPFAZNF> ..that’s my feeling too. <@U0XPR4NP4> we could skip it for now… but when <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/1633/> gets in, consensus package folder will go away

my concern is mostly that if we leave it open, we might have repeat mistakes

means it needs to be deliberate
